Local restaurants and stores are only a couple of minutes drive away. Be aware, this neighborhood is full of life and that does bring sound. Knowing we may encounter sounds during the night/morning we opted to turn the HVAC fan to "on" so it ran continuously while we slept. It was the perfect white noise to block any enthusiastic kids or waking roosters. We awoke peacefully on our own terms the next morning. Jill's place was the perfect stopover point for our road trip and we hope to return. It would be a great longer-term base for exploring the area. Highly recommended!

review_text:
I often wonder if people who give places like this these glowing reviews actually spend more than 5 minutes there. I spent $170 for one night here. Based on the fact that I had one of the worst night’s sleep ever, that’s about $70 more than it should have been. I’ll start with the positives. It’s clean and nice looking. The free bottles of water and snacks were a nice touch. The Wifi worked well; my laptop tested at about 40MB download speed. Now, for the not so positives.
I’ll start with the biggest problem, since the entire point of staying at a place is to have somewhere to sleep at night. The bedrooms were hot and stuffy, which made sleeping almost impossible…unless you like sleeping in 80 degree rooms. There are two small window air conditioner units, one in the living room, and one in the kitchen. Guess what rooms don’t have A/C? Both the bedrooms. So the back of the house is a totally different (and much warmer) temperature than the front of the house. Based on their size, and the fact that half the house was too warm, the A/C units don’t appear to be adequate to cool a 4 room house. This could easily be solved by having two stand-alone fans (one for each bedroom) for guests to use to cool down the bedrooms. It was in the mid 90s the day I checked in, and the bedrooms remained warm the entire time. There are ceiling fans in the bedrooms, but I had them on for several hours before I went to bed, and they did little to cool the bedrooms down. Additionally, as someone with sinus issues, having ceiling fans 5 feet above the bed blowing lukewarm air on me all night wasn’t an option. Oh, and if you’re looking for outside air to perhaps cool down the bedrooms at night, good luck with that. Neither of the bedroom windows open (and the other 2 windows have the AC units in them). So the house is hermetically sealed up like an office building.
Just when I thought the sleeping situation couldn’t get any worse, once I got into bed I realized it was equipped with a hard-as-a-rock memory foam mattress AND pillows. Good grief. If you know anything about memory foam, besides being rock hard, it also absorbs body heat…and, as I mentioned, I was already hot enough being in a hot bedroom. Out of frustration I was trying to beat the pillows throughout the night when I couldn’t sleep, in a futile attempt to soften them up. It didn’t work. So I spent the first 2-3 hours of my night trying to get to sleep and being half-awake most of the time. Finally around 4 AM I passed out, because at that point I was too exhausted even with the hot room and hard bedding.
Other “features” of the place: Upon entering the house, I was greeted with the smell of a potpourri explosion. I’m guessing that because the owner allows people to smoke pot in here, she needs to then mask the scent with some awful spray. Um, how about not allowing smoking instead?
The lighting in the bathroom is atrocious. Unlike every other bathroom on the planet, there are no lights above the bathroom mirror. Instead, the bathroom lighting is in the center of the bathroom. What does this mean? It means that while the shower is lit up decently from the lights, you get to see yourself in the dark in front of the mirror. The left side of your face will be partially lit, while the right side will be in the dark. So if you always wanted to look like the Batman villain “Two Face”, have I got the bathroom for you. Don’t try to shave your face in front of that mirror unless you’re feeling brave.
Last but not least, there is no way to adjust the volume on the TVs. They are Roku TVs, which theoretically should come with remotes with a volume button on them. Instead, the only remotes provided are the same ones you get when you buy a Roku box. With the AC blasting in the living room, it’s often hard to hear the TV. I searched through every menu option on the TV I could find, including Googling it to see if there was a trick, and nothing allowed me to adjust the TV volume. Because a lack of light is a theme in this house (the bathroom wasn’t the only room that was unnecessarily dark --- the kitchen was the only well lit room), I couldn’t see what may be on the side of the TV itself, so I even used the flashlight on my phone to search for a volume button on the TV, but couldn’t find any.
$170 for all this fun? I think not. Ironically, the Wifi name in this house is “Giggles”. I guess that could be one reaction to this place….maybe after some of the green stuff.

review_text: We needed a place to stay for the night on a long road trip & at first this place seemed to meet all the criteria—it was clean, the beds were comfortable, and it had everything we needed. As we were going to bed, we noticed that the walls between the duplex units were very thin—we could hear the neighbor’s TV through the wall & could hear them coughing in the bathroom. But it didn’t seem like a big deal until shortly after midnight, when the neighbor started playing music so loudly we could recognize the songs and song lyrics through the wall. It was so loud it was impossible to sleep even with earplugs & a pillow over my head, and the music didn’t stop until 4:45am. We were then able to sleep for a couple hours before we had to get up & get on the road. It’s obviously not the host’s fault that the guest/tenant on the other side played the music so loudly, but I left feeling like I needed to warn any light sleepers (or anyone who enjoys sleeping between midnight and 5am) that this might not be the place for you.
